docs.title: Deploying Watchtower in a Homelab Environment
docs.text: Watchtower is a useful tool for automatically updating running Docker containers. This guide will walk you through the steps to deploy Watchtower in your homelab environment.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A running Docker environment.
  • Basic knowledge of Docker and container management.

docs.title: Step 1: Pull the Watchtower Image
docs.text:
First, you need to pull the Watchtower image from Docker Hub. Open your terminal and run the following command:

docker pull containrrr/watchtower

docs.title: Step 2: Run Watchtower
docs.text:
To run Watchtower, you can use the following command. This will monitor all running containers and update them when a new image is available.

docker run -d \
  --name watchtower \
  -e WATCHTOWER_CLEANUP=true \
  -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock \
  containrrr/watchtower

docs.title: Explanation of the Command:
docs.text:
• -d: Runs the container in detached mode.
  • --name watchtower: Names the container "watchtower".
  • -e WATCHTOWER_CLEANUP=true: Automatically removes old images after updating.
  • -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock: Allows Watchtower to communicate with the Docker daemon.

docs.title: Step 3: Verify Watchtower is Running
docs.text:
You can check if Watchtower is running by executing:

docker ps

You should see the Watchtower container listed among your running containers.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: You have successfully deployed Watchtower in your homelab environment. Watchtower will now keep your Docker containers up to date automatically. For more advanced configurations, refer to the Watchtower documentation.

docs.title: Adding Prometheus to Grafana
docs.text: This document explains how to add Prometheus as a data source in Grafana for visualization.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Ensure that you have Grafana installed and running.
  • Prometheus should be up and running, collecting metrics.

docs.title: Steps to Add Prometheus to Grafana
docs.text:
1. Log in to Grafana: Open your web browser and navigate to your Grafana instance. Log in with your credentials.

  2. Add a Data Source:

  3. Click on the gear icon (⚙️) in the left sidebar to open the Configuration menu.

  4. Select "Data Sources."

  5. Select Prometheus:

  6. Click on the "Add data source" button.

  7. Choose "Prometheus" from the list of available data sources.

  8. Configure the Data Source:

  9. In the HTTP section, set the URL to your Prometheus server (e.g., http://localhost:9090).

  10. Adjust any other settings as necessary, such as access mode (Server or Browser).

  11. Save & Test:

  12. Click the "Save & Test" button to verify that Grafana can connect to your Prometheus instance.

  13. You should see a message indicating that the data source is working.

  14. Create a Dashboard:

  15. Navigate to the "+" icon in the left sidebar and select "Dashboard."

  16. Click on "Add new panel" to start visualizing your Prometheus metrics.

  17. Select Metrics:

  18. In the new panel, select your Prometheus data source.

  19. Use the query editor to select the metrics you want to visualize.

  20. Customize Your Panel:

  21. Adjust the visualization type, panel title, and other settings as needed.
  22. Click "Apply" to save your panel.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: You have successfully added Prometheus to Grafana. You can now create dashboards and visualize your metrics effectively. For further customization and advanced features, refer to the Grafana documentation.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: I have two cisco switches which i would be adding to prometheus; Catalyst 2560 and 3550. I will configure snmp on those switches.

docs.title: Enable SNMP on the Cisco Switches
docs.text:
Catalyst 3550 configuration 

interface FastEthernet 0/1
  ip address 192.168.0.99 255.255.255.0
  no switchport
!
ip default-gateway 192.168.0.1
snmp-server community public RO
Catalyst 2560 configuration 
interface Vlan1
  ip address 10.0.0.252 255.255.255.0
!
ip default-gateway

docs.title: Configure Prometheus to Scrape the Switches
docs.text:
In the Prometheus configuration file (prometheus.yml). 

scrape_configs:
  - job_name: 'cisco_switch_3550'
      static_configs:
        - targets: ['192.168.0.99:161']
  - job_name: 'cisco_switch_2560'
      static_configs:
        - targets: ['<SWITCH_IP>:161']

Restarting Prometheus to apply the changes 

docker restart <container-name/id>

  1. Verify the Configuration
  2. Access the Prometheus web interface.
  3. Navigate to the "Targets" page and ensure the Cisco switch is listed and being scraped successfully.

docs.title: Installing Prometheus & Grafana with Docker
docs.text:
Prometheus is a free tool that helps you monitor and alert you about your systems. Grafana is an open-source platform that helps you visualize and understand your data. We will integrate prometheus with grafana, which will be used as a data source for visualization

I will be installing both of them on a raspberry pi with Docker.

Creating an internal network for docker, which will be used to send information between the containers.

docker network create monitoring

docs.title: Dockerfile
docs.text:
services:
  prometheus:
     image: prom/prometheus
